title: The Prayer for Israel's Restoration
shortSummary: Psalm 80 is a heartfelt plea for God's mercy and restoration upon Israel, depicted as a vine planted and nurtured by God but now suffering under enemy attack. The psalmist appeals to God as the Shepherd of Israel to turn again and shine His face upon His people, promising renewed faithfulness in response to divine salvation.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - United Monarchy period, attributed to Asaph

keyCharacters.name: Asaph
keyCharacters.description: The psalmist and chief musician who composes this prayer, calling on God to restore Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Joseph
keyCharacters.description: Representing the tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh, Joseph is depicted as a flock led by God, symbolizing the northern kingdom of Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Ephraim, Benjamin, and Manasseh
keyCharacters.description: Tribes of Israel mentioned as those for whom God’s strength is invoked to save and restore.

definitions.definition: Heavenly beings symbolizing God's presence and glory, between whom God is said to dwell in the sanctuary.
A metaphor for suffering and sorrow, indicating the hardships experienced by God's people.
A common biblical symbol for Israel, representing God's chosen people whom He has planted and nurtured.
An expression meaning God’s favor and blessing, often associated with salvation and restoration.

outline.heading: Invocation and Petition for God’s Attention
outline.description: The psalmist calls on God as the Shepherd of Israel to listen and to restore His people, emphasizing God’s leadership over Joseph and the tribes.

outline.heading: Lament over God’s Anger and People’s Suffering
outline.description: A cry expressing distress over God’s prolonged anger, describing the people’s sorrow and the scorn of their enemies, with repeated pleas for God to turn and save.

outline.heading: God’s Planting of Israel as a Vine
outline.description: A vivid metaphor portraying Israel as a vine brought out of Egypt, carefully planted and flourishing, but now broken down and ravaged by enemies.

outline.heading: Prayer for God’s Return and Protection
outline.description: The psalmist implores God to look down and visit the vine, to protect the man at His right hand—likely a reference to the Davidic king—and to restore strength.

outline.heading: Renewed Commitment and Final Plea for Salvation
outline.description: The people promise not to turn away from God if He revives them, concluding with a final urgent appeal for God’s face to shine and bring salvation.

application: Trust God as the Good Shepherd who leads and cares for His people, even in times of distress.
Persist in prayer and repentance, asking God to turn His face toward us and restore us when we face spiritual decline.
Recognize that God’s blessings come with responsibility to remain faithful and not turn away from Him.
Encourage reliance on God’s strength rather than human efforts when confronting opposition or hardship.

keyVerses.text: Turn us again, O God, and cause thy face to shine; and we shall be saved.
keyVerses.significance: This verse encapsulates the psalm’s central plea for God’s favor and restoration leading to salvation.

keyVerses.text: Thou hast brought a vine out of Egypt: thou hast cast out the heathen, and planted it.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s sovereign role in establishing Israel as His chosen people.

keyVerses.text: Turn us again, O LORD God of hosts, cause thy face to shine; and we shall be saved.
keyVerses.significance: The concluding verse reiterates the earnest request for God’s mercy and the assurance of salvation upon His restoration.
